lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/AnonBot.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run AnonBot.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* Takes user inputs as commands and process them.
* If the input is not one of the supported commands below, NO new task will be created.
* Tasks are NOT saved when the program exits.
private static final String LOGO = "                          ____        _   " + System.lineSeparator()
private static final Scanner userInput = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");
// If there is no argument associated with that command
* Checks if the command argument contains a purely numeric string.
* @param commandArgument The argument portion of the user input.
* @return Whether the argument is a number of type String.
// We are only expecting 1 argument since this is only called by the `mark` and `unmark` commands
// We reject those with a mix of alphanumeric characters
* Gets the task number by converting the string to integer type.
* Assumes that the input has been checked and is valid.
* @param taskNumberString The task number that is of type String.
* @return The task number of type int.
* Parse the raw deadline description and break into its constituent parts.
* @return The formatted event description in the form {"Deadline Description", "/by info"}
// We currently do not check if the deadline task has the right format (/by)
* Parse the raw event description and break into its constituent parts.
* @return The formatted event description in the form {"Event Description", "/from info", "/to info"}
// We currently do not check if the event task has the right format (/from, /to)
* Creates a new Task with an associated task number and task type.
* @param taskNumber The task number this task is tagged to.
public Task(String taskDescription, int taskNumber, TaskType taskType) {
* Give the newly created task an associated task number.
* Sets the status of the associated task.
* @param isTaskDone Whether the task has been marked completed.
System.out.println("Cool, this task is now done:");
System.out.println("Oh okay, this task is now marked as undone:");
private static ArrayList<Task> taskList = new ArrayList<Task>();
public static void createNewTask(String taskDescription, Task.TaskType taskType) {
System.out.println("Invalid Task: Task Description is empty");

System.out.println("Alright. I have added this todo task: ");
System.out.println("Alright. I have added this deadline: ");

System.out.println("Now you have " + numberOfActiveTasks + " tasks in the list.");
* Prints out the whole list of tasks that have been added so far.

* @param taskNumber The task number to retrieve.
* @return The task associated with the task number. `null` if the task is not found.
